cleaned_text: The following updates were made prior to January 1, 2021. December 30, 2020 - Chief Clinical Officer Josh Adler provides [updates on vaccine distribution at UCSF](https://chancellor.ucsf.edu/blog/covid-19-vaccine-update). December 16, 2020 [The following message was sent by the Office of Communications: ] Dear UCSF Community, As COVID-19 infections continue to accelerate, your actions can help keep your family, friends, colleagues and those we serve safe as we celebrate the holiday season. As we welcome the start of the vaccine roll-out, remember that a vaccine is not a cure and it is important that we all continue to wear a mask, physically distance, wash our hands, and avoid unnecessary travel and gatherings. To stay informed, please review the following COVID-related updates: 1. Final 2020 Town Hall to Focus on Vaccines - NEW Join Chancellor Sam Hawgood and other UCSF leaders on [Friday, Dec. 18, at 4:00 p.m. via Zoom](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZv4m?url=https://calendar.ucsf.edu/event/ucsf_health_and_campus_covid-19_response_town_hall_6889#.X48l60JKjlw) for an update on UCSF's COVID-19 vaccine distribution efforts, COVID-19 testing and the latest pandemic news. Recordings of all COVID-19 Town Halls are [posted online](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZzTo?url=https://ucsfhealth.mediasite.com/Mediasite/Catalog/catalogs/ucsf-town-hall). 2. Vaccine Distribution Update - NEW UCSF received its first shipment of Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine today and has begun immunizing frontline workers as part of a multi-phased vaccine roll-out guided by public health priorities. More information and FAQs about UCSF's vaccination program are available on the [COVID-19 Vaccine Information Hub](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZ4sq?url=https://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/vaccines). 3. Final 2020 Dept. of Medicine Grand Rounds - NEW Join Department of Medicine Chair Bob Wachter on [Thursday, Dec. 17, at noon via Zoom](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZ8Gs?url=https://calendar.ucsf.edu/event/department_of_medicine_grand_rounds_-_covid-19_the_cdc_the_vaccine_roll-out_and_ethics_and_policy_issues_surrounding_immunity_passports#.X9kgYelKjlw) as he chats with former CDC Director and UCSF adjunct faculty member Julie Gerberding. Stanford University's David Studdert will discuss the ethics of "immunity passports." Also hear the latest on UCSF's COVID-19 vaccine distribution efforts. Recordings of previous Grand Rounds are available through the [Department of Medicine website](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZFgv?url=https://medicine.ucsf.edu/covid-19_grand_rounds). 4. California COVID Notify Available Statewide - NEW CA COVID Notify, the state's smartphone-based COVID-19 exposure notification system, is now available to all Californians. Visit the [COVID Notify landing page](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZK3x?url=http://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/ca-notify) for more information about the privacy-protected technology first piloted at UCSF. Please note that iPhone users who participated in the CA COVID Notify pilot must upgrade to the latest version of iOS in order to continue using the system. 5. Finance Road Show Available Online - NEW UCSF leaders presented an in-depth overview of UCSF and UCSF Health's $8 billion budget in the wake of COVID-19 as well as a 10-year outlook on its finances during a virtual road show on Dec. 11, 2020. A recording of that presentation is available for [viewing online](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZPSz?url=https://financesecure.ucsf.edu/ten-year-financial-plan-summary-2020) (MyAccess login required). 6. Holiday Travel and Testing Policy - REMINDER UCSF strongly recommends that members of our community [avoid all non-essential personal travel](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZVr1?url=https://chancellor.ucsf.edu/blog/important-update-covid-19-travel-policy-over-holidays) during the holiday season in order to help curb the concerning acceleration of infection. Anyone who must travel is advised to follow UCSF's [travel guidance](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDWZZF3?url=https://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/travel). UCSF offers asymptomatic COVID-19 testing to those returning from travel or concerned about a possible COVID-19 exposure. Updated information about how to get tested is available on the [UCSF COVID-19 testing webpage](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDXbgf5?url=https://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/testing#travel). 7. COVID-19 Financial Relief Programs Paused - REMINDER The application window for the second round of [COVID-19 Relief Programs](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDXbl27?url=https://chancellor.ucsf.edu/blog/covid-19-relief-program-closes-applications-dec-11) for UCSF and Benioff Children's Hospital Oakland employees and students has come to a close. We are pleased that the second round of funding will be fully distributed to our community, and we will open another round of applications if additional resources become available. Those who are in a position to donate are encouraged to do so on the [UCSF Qualified Disaster Relief Fund](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDXbpR9?url=http://makeagift.ucsf.edu/COVID-19-Qualified-Disaster-Relief) website. 8. Stay-at-Home Order in Effect Through Jan. 4, 2021 - REMINDER Due to the ongoing surge in COVID-19 cases, Bay Area public health officers have implemented a [regional stay-at-home order](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDXbvqC?url=https://cchealth.org/press-releases/2020/1204-Joint-Press-Release.pdf) that lasts until Jan. 4, 2021. The order has had minimal impact on UCSF operations thus far, but it may affect holiday plans and access to non-essential resources in the region. UCSF will monitor the situation and provide updates as needed. 9. Essential visits and events must receive advance approval in writing. UCSF's complete [visitor](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDXbzDF?url=https://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/visitors) and [events](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbDXb4dH?url=https://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/events) policies are available online. If you have questions, please contact [UCSF Emergency Management](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#5c3931392e72313b281c293f2f3a72393829). You can also sign up to receive text alerts about the latest UCSF news by texting "UCSF" to 333 111. Thank you for your continued dedication to safeguarding the health and well-being of the UCSF community and those we serve. December 5, 2020 [The following message was sent by the Office of Communications: ] Dear UCSF Community, Friday's [announcement by Bay Area health officers](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbr83j5B?url=https://cchealth.org/press-releases/2020/1204-Joint-Press-Release.pdf) to implement the State's [Regional Stay-At-Home Order](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbr83nVD?url=https://covid19.ca.gov/stay-home-except-for-essential-needs/#regional-stay-home-order) starting on Sunday, Dec. 6 in San Francisco, will have minimal impact to UCSF's operations, including research, which continues to operate at reduced density due to the pandemic. The Bay Area health officers said they are proactively imposing the stay-at-home order to close all sectors other than retail and essential operations beginning this weekend rather than waiting until the region's Intensive Care Unit (ICU) bed capacity drops below 15 percent [, the trigger Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Dec. 3.](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbr83stG?url=https://pikasso.bananatag.com/?v=1607198289947) This new stay-at-home order will take effect in Contra Costa, Santa Clara, and San Francisco counties and the city of Berkeley on Sunday, Dec. 6. It will take effect in Alameda county on Monday, Dec. 7 and in Marin county on Tuesday, Dec. 8. These restrictions will remain in effect until January 4, 2021. Here's what you should know about how the order affects UCSF's operations: Work From Home: UCSF continues to ask that all employees who can work from home continue to do so in order to limit on-site activities in accordance with the new order. Research: UCSF's research enterprise already has been scaled back due to the pandemic, operating at 25 percent capacity for clinical research and 50 percent for non-clinical, lab research. COVID-19-focused research and non-COVID-19 research may continue without additional restrictions. These reduced research density levels will remain the same until further notice. Please continue to follow [UCSF's research safety practices outlined here](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbr83xHJ?url=https://research.ucsf.edu/phase-3-expansion-onsite-ucsf-research-activities). Campus Life Services: SF Kebab, the eatery at the Mission Bay campus, will discontinue outdoor dining and will be open for take-out orders only. Both Bakar and Millberry Fitness Centers and the UCSF Library have already closed until further notice. Shuttle service will continue to operate at 25 percent capacity. Health Care: Scheduled elective procedures will continue as planned and appointments have not been cancelled at this time. Hospital capacity will be closely monitored and any changes to health care operations will be based on the UCSF Health surge plan. Education: All didactic and discussion-based courses for all programs will continue to run remotely. Health professions students will continue to participate in clinical placements and rotations and in essential on-campus activities as directed by their programs; they will be notified by their programs if there are any changes to those schedules. Graduate students who need to be physically present in their labs will continue to be included in the 50 percent maximum capacity; those who can do their research from home should continue to do so. As the pandemic continues to surge in California, teams across UCSF will monitor the situation daily and make adjustments as needed, so please stay tuned to all COVID-19 announcements and updates posted on the [UCSF coronavirus website](http://s.bl-1.com/h/dbr8364N?url=https://coronavirus.ucsf.edu/). As members of the UCSF community, we bear a special responsibility to serve as role models during this pandemic. As COVID-19 cases continue to rise, please remember to mask up, physically distance and follow all public health guidelines to help keep our community, our loved ones and those we serve safe during these challenging times. The following message was sent via UCSF WarnMe: The City and County of San Francisco has joined six other Bay Area jurisdictions in asking all residents to stay home except to meet essential needs.
